title: The luckiest generation: 25pc inflation and rock-bottom interest rates, who had it best for savings?
text:
This is the fourth in a series in which Telegraph Money will answer the age-old question: which generation has had it easiest with money? Previously we answered this question for property, pensions and investment returns.

Saving is the very first contact with personal finance we have and is the bedrock the rest of our money world is built upon. Long before consumers buy a house, invest or put money into a pension they will be hoarding their cash.

But some points in history have been better than others to be a saver – depending on your perspective.

Younger generations might bemoan low savings rates and say their parents and grandparents had it better banks paid out a lot more. But older age...
